newsitem.title: USA: Legg Mason manager likes cable, utilities - Barron's.
newsitem.headline: Legg Mason manager likes cable, utilities - Barron's.

text.p: A mutual fund manager for Baltimore's Legg Mason told the weekly financial tabloid Barron's that he was interested in cable companies like Tele-Communications Inc because they stood to gain from the rise in Internet use.

William Miller told the tabloid in an interview in its March 3 issue that he also thought that power utilities and online service providers like America Online were a good investment, however unattractive they might seem.

"Cable offers a better chance of finding values," he was quoted as saying. "Tele-Communications Inc, for instance. It's underperformed forever. They poured capital into a lot of questionable ventures. But they've become more focused on generating free cash."
Miller said he did not find the potential threat from satellite television to be very daunting. "(Their) growth is slowing."
Miller said cable companies could fend for themselves.
"They have big infrastructure in place," he said. "And there's a shortage of bandwidth, which is placing tremendous demands on the Internet service providers."
Miller said power utilities were becoming attractive as their sector was becoming deregulated.
He said utilities were not likely to hold onto inefficient plants that would cost them money in the new, competitive market.

"It looks to me like the high-cost generating facilities will be taken off the utilities' hands, which will give them a wad of cash," he said. "They'll become cash-rich and free-cash-flow-rich. And we follow the cash.

"UniCom, the old Commonwealth Edison, is down to the low 20s, from 28 a few weeks ago, and has a seven (percent) yield," he said. "New York State Electric and Gas has a yield pushing 6 (percent). Illinova pays out close to 5 (percent), and has been raising its dividend 11 (percent) a year. Eastern Utilities has almost a 9 (percent) dividend.
"Even if these stocks stall for the rest of the year, they should offer competitive returns with the overall market," he added.
Miller also said Wall Street had not realized how much cash America Online could generate.
He said it had no problems with receivables because membership fees were paid by credit card and it did not have to finance any inventory.
